body.head: Ballads and Lyrics of Socialism

lg.l: âO WHEREFORE do ye stand, a stern and steadfast band,
With your feet upon the pathway whence fame has turned away?â
We hunger not for fame, nor heed worldâs praise or blame,
Since fame and honour parted this many many a day!
âWhat colour do ye wearâwhat banner do ye bear
When you turn your faces fightwards, and make your weapons keen?â
Our bannerâs folds are red as our blood which we will shed
Ere that again be suffered which heretofore has been!
âWhom, then, do ye befriend, whose cause do ye defendâ
Are there any need such champions and fighting men as ye?â
Our arms and hearts are strong for all who suffer wrong,
And a world of woe can witness how many such there be!
âBut the Golden Calf stands high, and all its priests will cry,
âYe are heretics and outcasts if ye worship not as weâ!â
âTis our only boast toâday that we worship not as they,
And to their cursed idol will never bow the knee!
âWhat armies fight for you, O ye who are so few,
O ye who are so few in a world that is so wide?â
The Spirits of the Light shall do battle for the Rightâ
And who shall be against us, if these be on our side?

epigraph.q: Work while it is day : the night cometh, when no man can work

lg.l: IN the childhood of April, while purple woods
With the young yearâs blood in them smiled,
I passed through the lanes and the wakened fields,
And stood by the grave of the child.
And the pain awoke that is never dead
Though it sometimes sleeps, and again
It set its teeth in this heart of mine,
And fastened its claws in my brain:
It was hard and hard that the little hands
And the little wellâloved head
Should be out of reach of our living lips,
And be side by side with the dead.
For with trees about where the brown birds build,
And with long green grass above,
She lies in the cold sweet breast of earth
Beyond the reach of our love;
Whatever befalls in the coarse loud world,
We know she will never wake.
When I thought of the sorrow she might have known,
I was almost glad for her sake. . . .
Tears might have tired those kissâclosed eyes,
Grief hardened the mouth I kissed;
I was almost glad that my dear was dead
Because of the pain she had missed.
Oh, if I could but have died a child
With a white childâsoul like hers,
As pure as the windâflowers down in the copse,
Where the soul of the springtime stirs;
Or if I had only done with it all,
And might lie by her side unmoved!
I envied the very clods of earth
Their place near the child I loved.
And my soul rose up in revolt at life,
As I stood dryâeyed by her grave,
When sudden the grass of the churchyard sod
Rolled back like a green smooth wave;
The brown earth looked like the brown sea rocks,
The tombstones were white like spray,
And white like surf were the curling folds
Of the shrouds where the dead men lay;
For each in his place with his quiet face
I saw the dead lie low,
Who had worked and suffered and found life sad,
So many sad years ago.
Unchanged by time I saw them lie
As when first they were laid to rest,
The tired eyes closed, the sad lips still,
And the workâworn hands on the breast.
There were some who had found the green world so grey,
They had left it before their time,
And some were little ones like my dear,
And some had died in their prime;
And some were old, they had had their fill
Of bitter unfruitful hours;
And I knew that none of them, none, had known
A flower of a hope like ours!
Through their shut eyelids the dead looked up,
And without a voice they said:
âWe lived without hope, without hope we died,
And hopeless we lie here dead;
And death is better than life that draws
Pain in, as it draws in breath,
If life never dreams of a coming day
When life shall not envy death.
Through the dark of our hours and our times we lived,
Uncheered by a single ray
Of such hope as lightens the lives of you
Who are finding life hard toâday;
With our little lanterns of human love
We lighted our dark warm nightâ
But you in the chill of the dawn are set
With your face to the eastern light.
Freedom is waiting with hands held out
Till you tear the veil from her faceâ
And when once men have seen the light of her eyes,
And felt her divine embrace
The light of the world will be risen indeed,
And will shine in the eyes of men,
And those who come after will find life fair,
And their lives worth living then!
Will you strive to the light in your loud rough world,
That these things may come to pass,
Or lie in the shadow beside the child,
And strive to the sun through the grass?â
âMy world while I may, âI cried; âbut you
Whose lives were as dark as your grave?â
âWe too are a part of the coming light,â
They called through the smooth green wave.
Their white shrouds gleamed as the flood of green
Rolled over and hid them from meâ
Hid all but the little hands and the hair,
And the eyes that I always see.
ONE stood with his face to the light;
He held a sceptre of song
That ruled menâs souls till they strove to the right,
And set their feet on the wrong.
âI am but a slave,â he said,
âThe servant of man am I,
To sing of the life that is more than bread,
And the deaths that are life to die.
âAnd the might of my song shall sway
The millions who sit in shame,
Till they cast their idols of gold away,
And worship the true Godâs name.â
So he sang, and the nations heard
Through their drunken sleep of years,
And their limbs in their golden fetters stirred
As he sang to their drowsy ears.
Hope woke, in her spellbound bowers,
And gave heed to each clear keen word,
Till Love looked out from a net of flowers,
And called to his heartâand he heard.
And his song rose higher, more sweet,
As his dreams rose more sweet, more high:
ââTis Love shall aid me, and shall complete
The spell I shall conquer by!
âWe two to menâs souls will sing,
And the work shall be ours, be ours;
Together welcome the thorns that bring
More fruit than the sweetest flowers!â
But the woman he loved said âNo!
To me all your soul is due,
Can I share with a world, whatever its woe,
My heartâs one treasure, you?
âThere are plenty to sing of the right
And give their lives for the truthâ
But you are mine, and shall sing delight,
And beauty, and love, and youth.
âFor these are the songs men love,
These stir their dull brains like wine.
They hate the songs you were proudest of
In the days when you were not mine.
âAnd if for the world you sing
It will pay you with fame and gold,
And the fame and the gold to me you shall bring
For my heart and my hands to hold.
âBesidesâwhat steads it to try,
One man against all the rest?
Let the world and its rights and its wrongs go by,
And hide your eyes on my breast!â
Then the man bowed down his head
And she crowned him with roses sweet;
And he laboured for fame and bread,
And laid his wage at her feet.
And the millions who starve and sin,
He shut them out of his life
Where she was alone shut inâ
His ruin, his prize, his wife.
And all that he might have been,
And all that he might have done,
These lie with the things that shall not be seen
For ever under the sun.
His children play round his knee,
But he sighs as they come and goâ
For they speak of visions he cannot see,
In a tongue that he used to know.
He sings of love and of flowers,
And forgets what they used to mean,
For gold is lord of his empty hours,
And fame of his soul is queen.
And the woman has long possessed
What she bade him win for her sake;
But she holds with the gold accurst unrest,
And the fame with a wild heartâache.
For the light in her eyes is dim,
Or dim are his eyes that gaze.
There is no light that can light for him
The gloom of his sordid days.
He will die, and his name be enrolled
Where marble makes mock of clay;
(Oh, the pitiful clay, made brave with gold!)
And there let it rot away!
One stood in the way of life
And said: âI will serve and strive
And never weary of strife
For just so long as I live.
âThe sum of service Iâm worth
I swear it, beyond recall,
To the mother of all, the earth,
To men, the brothers of all.
âI have no voice for a song,
No trumpet nor lyre is mine,
But my sword is sharp, and my arm is strong:
Liberty! these are thine!â
So he followed where high hopes led,
And he paused not for blame or praise,
But ever rejoiced to tread
The roughest and rightest ways.
He scorned ambitions and powers,
Delight was to him but a word,
Till Love looked out from a brake a flowers
And called to his heart, and he heard.
Then the manâs whole soul cried sore:
âI am tired of patience and pain!
What if the lights that have gone before
Should be but visions and vain?
âWhy should my youth be spent
In following a marshâlight gleam?
Why should my manhood be content
With what may be but a dream?
âThe sword I am used to wield
Is as much as my hands can hold,
I will turn aside from the battleâfield
To the fields where men gather gold.
âFor while I carry the sword
I can hold neither gold nor youâ
And the sword is heavy, and your least word
Is music my life sings to!â
But the woman who loved him spake,
She spake brave words with a sighâ
âRather than drop the sword for my sake
Turn its point to your heart and die!
âIt is better to die than live
If life means nothing but greed
To clutch the gifts that the world can give
And turn your back on its need.
âAnd I have my lifeâwork too,
A banner to bear have I;
Shall my flag be dragged in the dust by you,
Who should help me to hold it high?
âHard looks lifeâs every line
When the colours of love are effaced,
But death would be harder, O heart of mine,
After a life disgraced!
âAnd what though we never see
Sweet Loveâs sweet fruit at its best;
My childrenâs play at your knee,
Your babyâs sleep at my breast?
âOnly one life is oursâ
Shall we die with no worldâs work done,
Having covered our shame with flowers,
And shrunk from sight of the sun?
âNo! Be the sword for him,
Banner of light for meâ
Voice at the heart when the eyes grown dim,
âLiberty! This for thee!ââ
Then he bowed him low at her knees,
And she gave him the thorny crown
Which whoso wears knows no rest nor ease
Till Death bids him lay it down.
And they turned, and they passed away
To parting, and longing, and tears,
To carry the sword and the flag away
Through the cold clean desolate years,
To work for the world, and to hear
When the long race nearly is run,
Like a voice in a dream, a voice most dear,
âFaithful and good, well done!â
And no man remembers his name,
Nor hers, who was never his wife.
Their names are written in letters of flame
In the book of eternal life.
WHEN all the night is horrible with clamour
Of voiceless curses darker than the night,
When light of sun there is not, neither starshine,
Nor any beacon on the hill of Right,
Shine, O thou Light of Life, upon our pathwayâ
Freedom, be thou our light!
Since all lifeâs ways are difficult and dreary,
And false steps echo through eternity,
And there is naught to lean on as we journey
By paths not smooth as downward paths would be,
We have no other helpâwe need no other;
Freedom, we lean on thee!
The slaveâs base murmur and the threats of tyrants,
The voice of cowards who cringe and cry âRetreat,â
The whisper of the world, âCome where power calls thee!â
The whisper of the flesh, âLet life be sweet.â
Since all these with thy divine commanding;
Guide thou thy childrenâs feet!
For thee, for thee we bear the cross, the banner,
For thee are all our battles fought and won;
For thee was every prayer we ever uttered,
For thee has every deed of ours been done;
To thee we pressâto thee, triumphant splendour,
O Freedom, lead us on!
Where thou shalt lead we do not fear to follow.
Thou hast our hearts; we follow them in thee.
Spirit of Light, whatever thou shalt show us,
Strong in the faith, we shall not fear to see;
We reach to thee through all the waves of darkness
Of all the days to be.
THIS is the story of Renyi,
And when you have heard it through,
Pray God He send no trial like his
To try the faith of you.
And if is doom be upon you,
Then may God grant you this:
To fight as good a fight as he,
And win a crown like his!
He was strong and handsome and happy,
Beloved and loving and young,
With eyes that men set their trust in,
And the fire of his soul on his tongue.
He loved the Spirit of Freedom,
He hated his countryâs wrongs,
He told the patriotsâ stories,
And he sang the patriotsâ songs.
With mother and sister and sweetheart
His safe glad days went by,
Till Hungary called on her children
To arm, to fight, and to die.
âGoodâbye to mother and sister;
Goodâbye to my sweet sweetheart;
I fight for youâyou pray for me,
We shall not be apart!â
The women prayed at the sunrise,
They prayed when the skies grew dim;
His mother and sister prayed for the Cause,
His sweetheart prayed for him.
For mother and sister and sweetheart,
But most for the true and the right,
He low laid down his own lifeâs hopes
And led his men to fight.
Skirmishing, scouting, and spying,
Nightâwatch, attack, and defeat;
The resolute, desperate fighting,
The hopeless, reluctant retreat;
Ruin, defeat, and disaster,
Capture and loss and despair,
And half of his regiment hidden,
And only this man knew where!
Prisoner, fast bound, sore wounded,
They brought him roughly along
With his body as weak and broken
As his spirit was steadfast and strong
Before the Austrian generalâ
âWhere are your men?â he heard;
He looked black death in its ugly face
And answered never a word.
âWhere is your regiment hidden?
Speakâyou are pardoned straight.
No? We can find dumb dogs their tongues,
You rebel reprobate!â
They dragged his mother and sister
Into the open hall.
âGive up your men, if these women
Are dear to your heart at all!â
He turned his eyes on his sister,
And spoke to her silently;
She answered his silence with speaking,
And straight from her heart spoke she:
âIf you betray your country,
You spit on our fatherâs name;
And what is life without honor?
And what is death without shame?â
He looked on the mother who bore him
And her smile was splendid to see;
He hid his face with a bitter cry,
But never a word said he.
âSon of my bodyâbe silent!
My days at the best are few,
And I shall know how to give them,
Son of my heart, for you!â
He shivered, set teeth, kept silence:
With never a plaint or cry
The women were slain before him,
And he stood and he saw them die.
Then they brought his lovely beloved,
Desire of his heart and eyes.
âSay where your men are hidden,
Or say that your sweetheart dies.â
She threw her arms about him,
She laid her lips to his cheek:
âSpeak! for my sake who love you!
Love, for our loveâs sake, speak!â
His eyes are burning and shining
With the fire of immortal disgraceâ
Christ! walk with him in the furnace
And strengthen his soul for a space!
Long he looked at his sweetheart
His eyes grew tender and wet;
Closely he held her to him,
His lips to her lips were set.
âSee! I am young! I love you!
I am not ready to die!
One word makes us happy for ever,
Together, you and I.â
Her arms round his neck were clinging,
Her lips his cold lips caressed;
He suddenly flung her from him,
And folded his arms to his breast.
She wept, she shrieked, she struggled,
She cursed him in Godâs name,
For the woe of her early dying,
And for her dyingâs shame.
And still he stood, and his silence
Like fire was burning him through,
Then the muskets spoke once, through his silence,
And she was silent too.
They turned to torture him further,
If further might beâin vain;
He had held his peace in that threefold hell,
And he never spoke again:
The end of the uttermost anguish
The soul of the man could bear,
Was the madhouse where tyrants bury
The broken shells of despair.
By the heaven renounced in her service,
By the hell thrice braved for her sake,
By the years of madness and silence,
By the heart that her enemies brake;
By the young lifeâs promise ruined,
By the years of too living death,
By the passionate selfâdevotion,
And the absolute perfect faith;
By the thousands who know such anguish,
And share such divine renown,
Who have borne them bravely in battle,
And won the conquerorâs crown;
By the torments her children have suffered,
By the blood that her martyrs will give,
By the deaths men have died at her altars,
By these shall our Liberty live!
In the silence of tears, in the burden
Of the wrongs we some day will repay,
Live the brothers who died in all ages
For the Freedom we live for toâday!
YES, read the pages of the oldâworld story,
Of kings of noble deed and noble thought
Of heroes whose resplendent crown of glory
Bound their wide brows, unsought.
But be not sad because their work is ended,
And they have rest which life so long denied:
They still live in the world which they befriended,
For which they lived and died.
Great deeds can never die : all through the ages
Their fruits increasing ever grow and spread,
And many a deed unnamed in written pages
Lived onceâand is not dead.
And, God be praised, manâs work is not completed,
There still is work on earth for men to do;
Not yet, not yet are all the false defeated,
Nor yet crowned all the true.
Still the world needs brave deeds and true hearts many,
Not yet are all the noble battles won!
We too, we too may do deeds great as any
That ever yet were done.
âSWEET are the lanes and the hedges, the fields made red with the clover,
With tall fieldâsorrel, and daisies, and golden buttercups glowing;
Sweet is the way through the woods, where at sundown maiden and lover
Linger by stile or by bank where clematis garlands are growing.
Fair is our world when the dew and the dawn thrill the halfâwakened roses,
Fair when the cornâfields grown warm with poppies in noonlight gleaming,
Fair through the long afternoon, when hedges and hayfields lie dreaming,
Fair as in lessening light the last convolvulus closes.
âScent of geranium and musk that in cottage windows run riot,
Breath from the grass that is down in the meadows each side the highway,
Slumberous hush of the churchyard where we one day may lie quiet,
Murmuring wind through the leaves bent over the meadow byway,
Deeps of cool shadow, and gleams of light on high elmtops shining,
Such peace in the dim green brake as the town, save in dreams, knows never,
But in, through, under it all, the old pain follows us everâ
Ever the old despair, the old unrest and repining.
âDark is the Cityâs face; but her children who know her find her
Mother to them who are brothers, mindful of brotherhoodâs duty;
To each of us, lonely, unhelped, the grave would be warmer, kinder,
Than the cold unloving face of our world of blossom and beauty.
Poverty deep and dark cowers under the thatch with the swallows,
Cruel disease lies hid in the changeful breast of the waters,
Drink sets snares for our sons, and shame digs graves for our daughters,
Want and care crush the flower of a youth that no lifeâfruit follows.
âWhat are the woodland sweets, the meadowâs fair flowery treasure,
When we are hungry and sad, and stupid with work and with sorrows?
Leisure for nothing but sleep, and with heart but for sleep in our leisure;
The work of toâday still the same as yesterdayâs work, and toâmorrowâs.
Ever the weary roundâthe treadmill of innocent livesâ
Hopeless and helpless, and bowing our back like a houndâs to the lashes;
What can seem fair to the eyes that are smarting and sore with the ashes
Blown from the fires that consume the souls of our children and wives?
âDreams sometimes we have had of an hour when we might speak plainly,
Raise the mantle and show how the iron eats into our bosom,
The rotting root of the Nation, the worm at the heart of its blossom,
Dreaming we said, âWe will speak, when the time for it comes, not vainly.â
Ahâbut the time comes neverâLife, we are used to bear it,
Starved are our brains and grow not, our hands are fit but for toiling,
If we stretched them out their touch to our mastersâ hand would be soiling;
Weak is our voice with disuseâtoo weak for our lords to hear it!â
âSo has the spark died out that the torch of hope dropped among you?
So is the burden bound more fast to the shrinking shoulder?
Far too faint are your cries to be heard by the men who wrong you?
And if they heard they are high, and the air as men rise grows colder!
Yet you are men though so weak, and in mine and workshop your brothers,
Stronger in head, and in heart not less sad, for deliverance are striving;
These will stand fast, and will face the cruel unjust and ungiving,
And you in our ranks shall be, our hearts fast clasped in each otherâs!
âFor in the night of our sorrow cold lights are breaking and brightening
Out in the eastern sky; through the drifting clouds, windâdriven,
Over the earth new gleams and glories are laughing and lightening,
Keener the air grows, clearer; brighter the face of the heaven.
Turn we our face to the eastâoh, wind of the dawn, blow to us
Freshness and strength and resolve! The star of old faith grows paler
Before the eyes of our Freedom, though still wrathâs red mists veil her,
For this is our battle day; revenge, like our blood, runs through us.
âThis is our vengeance day. Our masters, made fat with our fasting,
Shall fall before us like corn when the sickle for harvest is strong:
Old wrong shall give might to our armâremembrance of wrong shall make lasting
The graves we will dig for the tyrants we bore with too much and too long.
The sobs of our starving children, the tears of our heartsick mothers,
The moan of your murdered manhood crushed out by their wanton pressure,
The wail of the lifeâlong anguish that paid the price of their pleasure,
These will make funeral music to speed the lost souls of them, brothers!
âShoulder to shoulder we march, and for those who go down âmid the fighting
With rifles in hand and pikes, and the red flag over them flying,
Glad shall our hearts be for themâwho die when our sun is lighting
The warm, wide heavens, and sheds its lovely light on their dying.
Fight, though we lose our dearestâfight, though the battle rages
Fiercer and hotter than ever was fight in the world before:
We must fightâhow can men do less? If we die, what can men do more?
And the sun of Freedom shall shine across our graves to the ages!â
I HAD a star to sing by, a beautiful star that led,
But when I sang of its splendour the world in its wisdom said:
âSweet are your songs, yet the singer sings but in madness when
He hymns but stars unbeholden of us his fellows of men;
âGlowâworms we see and marshlights; sing us sweet songs of those
For the guerdons we have to give you, laurel and gold and rose;
Or if you must sing of stars, unseen of your brother man,
Go, starve with your eyes on your vision; your star may save if it can!â
So I said, âIf I starve and die I never again shall see
The glory, the high white radiance that hallows the world for me;
I will sing their songs, if it must be, and when I have golden store,
I will turn from the marsh and the glowâworms, and sing of my star once more.â
So I walked in the warm wet byâways, not daring to lift my eyes
Lest love should drive me to singing my star supreme in the skies,
And the world cried out, âWe will crown him, he sings of the lights that are,
Glories of marshlight and glowâworms, not visions vain of a star!â
I said, âNow my brows are laurelled, my hands filled full of their gold,
I will sing the starry songs that these earthworms bade withhold.
It is time to sing of my star!â for I dreamed that my star still shone,
Then I lifted my eyes in my triumph. Night! night! and my star was gone.

div.head: The Sick Journalist
div.l: THROB, throb, throb, weariness, ache, and pain!
Oneâs heart had oneâs eyes on fire,
And never a spark in oneâs brain.
The stupid paper and ink,
That might be turned into gold,
Lie here unused,
Since oneâs brain refused
To do its tricksâas of old.
One can suffer still, indeed,
But one cannot think any more.
Thereâs no fire in the grate,
No food on the plate,
And the Eastâwind shrieks through the door.
The sunshine grins in the street:
It used to cheer me like wine,
Now it only quickens my brainâs sick beat;
And the children are crying for bread to eat
And I cannot write a line!
Molly, my petâdonât cry,
Father canât write if you doâ
And anyhow, if you only knew,
Itâs hard enough as it is.
There, give old daddy a kiss,
And cuddle down on the floor;
Weâll have some dinner byâandâby.
Now, fool, try! Try once more!
Hold your head tight in your hands,
Bring your will to bear!
The children are starvingâyour little onesâ
While you sit fooling there.
Beth, with her golden hair
Moll, with her rough, brown headâ
here they areâsee!
Against your knee,
Waiting there to be fed!â
I cannot bear their eyes.
Their soft little kisses burnâ
They will cry again
In vain, in vain,
For the food that I cannot earn.
If I could only write
Just half a column or so
On âThe Prospects of Trade,â or âThe Irish Question,â or âWhy are Wages so Low?ââ
The printers are waiting for copy now,
Iâve had my next weekâs screw,
Thereâll be nothing more till Iâve written something,
God! what am I to do?
If I could only write!
The paper glares up white
Like the cursed white of the heavy stone
Under which she lies alone;
And the ink is black like death,
And the room and the window are black.
Molly, Mollyâthe sunâs gone out,
Cannot you fetch it back?
Did I frighten my little ones?
Never mind, daddy dropped asleepâ
Cuddle down closely, creep
Close to his knee
And daddy will see
If he canât do his writing. Vain!
I shall never write again!
Oh, God! was it like a love divine
To make their lives hang on my pen
When I cannot write a line?

lg.l: SLEEP, sleep, my little baby dear,
Thee shall no want or pain come near;
Sleep softly on thy downy nest,
Or on this lace veiled motherâbreast.
Thy cradle is all silken lined,
Wrought roses on thy curtains twined,
Warm woolly blankets oâer thee spread,
And soft white pillows for thy head.
Much gold those little hands shall hold,
And wealth about thy life shall fold,
And thou shalt see nor pain nor strife,
Nor the low ills of common life.
These little feet shall never tread
Except on paths softâcarpeted,
And all lifeâs flowers in wreaths shall twine
To deck that darling head of thine.
Thou shalt have overflowing measure
Of wealth and joy and peace and pleasure,
And thou shalt be right charitable
With all the crumbs that leave thy table.
And thou shalt praise God every day
For His good gifts that come thy way,
And again thank Him, and again,
That thou art not as other men.
For âmidst thy wealth thou wilt recallâ
âTis to Godâs grace thou owest it all;
And when allâs spent that life has given,
Thouâlt have a golden home in heaven.
Sleep, little baby, sleep,
Though the wind is cruel and cold,
And my shawl that Iâve wrapped thee in
Is old and ragged and thin;
And my hand is too frozen to holdâ
Yet my bosomâs still warmâso creep
Close to thy mother, and sleep!
Sleep, little baby, and rest,
Though we wander alone through the night,
And there is no food for me,
No shelter for me and thee.
Through the windows red fires shine bright,
And tables show, heaped with the bestâ
But thereâs naught for us thereâso rest.
Sleep, you poor little thing!
Just as pretty and dear
As any fine ladyâs child.
Oh, but my heart grows wild!â
Is it worth while to stay here?
What good thing from life will spring
For youâyou poor little thing?
Sleep, you poor little thing!
Mine, my treasure, my ownâ
I clasp you, I hold you close,
My darling, my bird, my rose!
Rich mothers have hearts like stone,
Or else some help they would bring
To youâ you poor little thing?
Sleep, little baby, sleepâ
If some good, rich mother would take
My dear, I would kiss thee, and then
Never come near thee againâ
Not though my heart should break!
I could leave thee, dear, for thy sakeâ
For the river is dark and deep,
And gives sleep, little baby, sleep!
THE spring is here, and the long nights grow
Less bitterly cold than awhile ago;
Our rags serve their purpose now, and keep
Warmth enough in us to let us sleep.
The rain that trickles down our walls
No longer seems to freeze as it falls;
There was dust, not mud, on our feet toâday
Thereâs some green in a flowerâpot over the way;
The skyâstrip over the courtâs changed hue,
From dull yellowâgrey to clear greyâblue;
Through our broken windows no more the storm
Laughs and shrieks as we try to keep warm,
But through dusty panes the long sunbeams peer,
For the spring is here.
Small joy the greenness and grace of spring
To grey hard lives like our own can bring.
A drowning man cares little to think
Of the lights on the waves where he soon must sink.
The greenest garments the spring can wear
Are black already with our despair:
Earth will be one with us soonâshall we care
If snow or sunshine be over us there,
Or if wintry the world be we found so drear,
Or if spring be here?
In the western half of our Christian town
The Winter only pretends to frown,
And when his undreaded rage is done,
The âLondon seasonâ they say is begun.
With wine, feast, revelling, laugh and song,
The hours roseâgarlanded dance along,
The whirl of wickedness wilder grows
In this western camp of our masterâfoes;
They fight with each otherâthe victors take
The largest share of the wealth we make;
They spend on their horses, their women, their wives,
The money wrung from our blasted lives:
It is theirs to enjoyâit is ours to pay.
Do they never dream of a reckoning day,
When the lives they have wrecked shall be counted up,
And measured the blood that has brightened their cup,
When we who have worked shall take payment due,
And they for their work shall have payment too?
Do they dream of that coming hour? Not they!
Their feet flit fast down the smooth steep way,
They see not the waiting snakes that hide
In the hothouse flowers at their lifeâpathâs side,
They know no justice, no pity, no fearâ
But the spring is here!
Yesâhere! In the hope we had almost lost,
That has sprung to bud after long yearsâ frost;
In this fire in our veins that cries, âGive youth,
Love, manhood, life, for the Right and the Truthâ;
In our steady purpose, for Freedomâs sake,
Through custom, privilege, âfate,â to break;
In the brains of the thinkers, the arms of the men
Who will strike, and strike, and still strike again,
Till they cut our way to the land of flowers,
And the summer of freedom at last is oursâ
In these is the spring. The winter was soreâ
It is over and done, and will come no more.
The fruit will grow with the changing year,
Though only the blossoms now appear;
For the sake of the fruit the blossoms are dear,
And the spring is hereâthe spring is here.
âWHAT of the garden I gave?â
God said to me;
âHast thou been diligent to foster and save
The life of flower and tree?
How have the roses thriven,
The lilies I have given
The pretty scented miracles that spring
And summer come to bring?â
âMy garden is fair and dear,â
I said to God;
âFrom thorns and nettles I have kept it clear,
Greenâtrimmed its sod.
The rose is red and bright,
The lily a live delight;
I have not lost a flower of all the flowers
That blessed my hours.â
âWhat of the child I gave?â
God said to me;
âThe little little one I died to save
And gave in trust to thee?
How have the flowers grown
That in its soul were sown,
The lovely living miracles of youth
And hope and joy and truth?â
âThe childâs face is all white,â
I said to God;
âIt cries for cold and hunger in the night;
Its little feet have trod
The pavement muddy and cold,
It has no flowers to hold,
And in its soul the flowers you set are dead.â
âThou fool!â God said.
THERE is a garden, made for our delight,
Where all the dreams we dare not dream come true.
I know it, but I do not know the way.
We slip and stumble in the doubtful night,
Where everything is difficult and new,
And clouds our breath has made obscure the day.
The blank, unhappy towns, where sick men strive,
Still doing work that yet is never done,
The hymns to Gold that drown their desperate voice:
The weeds that grow where once corn stood alive,
The black injustice that puts out the sun;
These are our portion, since they are our choice.
Yet there the garden blows, with rose on rose,
The sunny shadowâdappled lawns are there,
There the immortal lilies, heavenlyâsweet.
Oh roses that for us shall not unclose!
Oh lilies that we shall not pluck or wear!
Oh dewy lawns untrodden by our feet!
SQUALID street after squalid street,
Endless rows of them, each the same,
Black dust under your weary feet,
Dust upon every face you meet,
Dust in their hearts, tooâor so it seemsâ
Dust in the place of dreams.
Spring in her beauty thrills and thrives,
Here men hardly have heard her name.
Work is the end and aim of their livesâ
Work, work, work! for children and wives;
Work for a life which, when it is won,
Is the saddest under the sun!
Workâone dark and unending round
In black dull workshops, out of the light;
Work that othersâ ease may abound,
Work that delight for them may be found,
Work without hope, without pause, without peace,
That only in death can cease.
Brothers, who live glad lives in the sun,
What of these men, at work in the night?
God will ask you what you have done;
Their lives be required of youâevery oneâ
Ye, who were glad and who liked life well,
While they did your workâin hell!

div.head: Londonâs Voices
Speak to Two SoulsâWho thus Reply:

lg.l: IN all my work, in all the childrenâs play,
I hear the ceaseless hum of London near;
It cries to me, I cannot choose but hear
Its neverâending wail, by night and day.
So many millionsâis it vain to pray
That all may win such peace as I have here,
With books, and work, and little children dear?â
That flowers like mine may grow along their way?
Through all my happy life I hear the cry,
The exceeding bitter cry of human pain,
And shudder as the deathless wail sweeps by.
I can do nothingâeven hope in vain
That the bright light of peace and purity
In those lost souls may ever shine again!
âMid pine woodsâ whisper and the hum of bees
I heard a voice that was not bee nor wood:
âHere, in the city, Gold has trampled Good.
Come thou, do battle till this strife shall cease!â
I left the mill, the meadows and the trees,
And came to do the little best I could
For these, Godâs poor; and, oh, my God, I would
I had a thousand lives to give for these!
What can one hand do âgainst a world of wrong?
Yet, when the voice said, âCome!â how could I stay?
The foe is mighty, and the battle long
(And love is sweet, and there are flowers in May),
And Good seems weak, and Gold is very strong;
But, while these fight, I dare not turn away.
DARK is the night; and through its haunted shadows
We blindly grope and stumbleâsometimes fall;
No star is near enough to light the darkness,
And priestâlit tapers cast no light at all,
Save such a feeble and delusive glimmer
As nightâlamps cast upon a sickâroom wall.
Yet, each a torch we bearâlit or unlighted;
Burning for self it is a marshâlightâs gleam,
Kindled for others âtis the child of sunlight,
And darkness shrinks through twilight at its beam.
Were each torch duly lit, O world long darkened,
How would you bear the sudden light supreme?
Vague dreams and vain! See, thou who idly dreamest
Of what would be if every torch were lit,
See where thine own smoulders a wasted ember,
Thy torchâfor noblest uses framed and fit.
Light thine own torchâand hold it to thy brother,
And his shall kindle at the flame of it.
KNOWING our needs, hardly knowing our powers,
Hear how we cry to you, brothers of ours!â
Brothers in nature, pulse, passions, and pains,
Our sins in you, and your blood in our veins.
First in your palace, or last in our den,
Basest or best, we are all of us men!
Justice eternal cries out in our name,
What is the least common manhood can claim?
âFood that we make for you,
Money we earn:
Give us our share of themâ
Give us our turn.â
You with the land and the money, we make
Out of our lives the new wealth that you take.
Have we earned only such pitiful dole
As just holds worn body to desolate soul?
When that soul is bewildered each day and perplext
With the problem of how to get bread for the next,
Is it better to end it, as some of us do,
Or to fight it out bravely, still calling to youâ
âFood that we make for you,
Money we earn:
Give us our share of themâ
Give us our turn.â?
Ever more passionate grows our demandâ
Give us our share of our food and our land:
Give us our rights, make us equal and freeâ
Let us be all we are not, but might be.
Our sons would be honest, our daughters be pure,
If our wage were more certain, your vices less sureâ
Oh, you who are forging the fetters we feel,
Hear our wild protest, our maddened appealâ
âFood that we make for you,
Money we earn:
Give us our share of themâ
Give us our turn.â
Hear us, and answer, while Time is your friend,
Lest we be answered by God in the end;
Lest, when the flame of His patience burns low,
We be the weapon He shapes for His blowâ
Lest with His foot on your necks He shall stand,
And appeal that you spurned be newâborn as command,
And thunder your doom, as you die by the rod
Of the vengeance of man through the justice of God.
âFood that we make for you,
Money we earn:
Give us our share of themâ
Give us our turn.â
WE climb the hill; the mist conceals
That valley where we could not stay;
Surely this hillâs crest, gained, reveals
The glory of the sunlit day.
The hill is climbed. Still shadowâlandâ
Still darkling looms another hill.
Oh, weary feet!âclimb that to find
A new ascent, âmid shadows still!
We dare not stop or think of rest,
This one hill may be all that lies
Between us and our soulsâ desireâ
The splendour of the eastern skies.
Through long long lives we till and tend,
Sow, weed, and water, all in vain;
Without the flower we looked to find,
Each year springs, blooms, and dies again.
Bowed down with our unanswered prayers,
Our face averted from our past,
We watch each year grow green, and cry,
âSurely this brings our flower at last!â
Failure on failure! What! tired out?
Too tired to live? Ah, dare you die
When this new year may bud and bear
Your longedâfor flower of Liberty?
AH me, how hot and weary here in town
The days crawl by!
How otherwise they go my heart records,
Where the marsh meadows lie
And white sheep crop the grass, and seagulls sail
Between the lovely earth and lovely sky.
Here the sun grins along the dusty street
Beneath pale skies:
Hark! spiritless, sad tramp of toiling feet,
Hoarse hawkers, curses, criesâ
Through these I hear the song that the sea sings
To the far meadowlands of Paradise.
O goldenâlichened church and redâroofed barnâ
O long sweet daysâ
O changing, unchanged skies, straight dykes all gay
With sedge and water maceâ
O fair marsh land desirable and dearâ
How far from you lie my lifeâs weary ways!
Yet in my darkest night there shines a star
More fair than day;
There is a flower that blossoms sweet and white
In the sad city way.
That flower blooms not where the wide marshes gleam,
That star shines only when the skies are gray.
For here fair peace and passionate pleasure wane
Before the light
Of radiant dreams that make our lives worth life,
And turn to noon our night:
We fight for freedom and the souls of menâ
Here, and not there, is fought and won our fight!
ACROSS the grim, gray northern sea
The Danish warships went,
Snakeâshaped, and manned by mighty men
On blood and plunder bent;
And they landed on a smiling landâ
The gardenâland of Kent.
They sacked the farms, they spoiled the corn,
They set the ricks aflame;
They slew the men with axe and sword,
They slew the maids with shame;
Until, to Canterbury town,
Made mad with blood, they came.
Archbishop Alphege walked the wall
And looked down on the foe.
âNow fly, my lord!â his monks implored,
âWhile yet a man may go!â
âShame on you, monks of mine,â he cried,
âTo shame your bishop so!
âWhat, would you have the shepherd flee
Like any hireling knave?
What, leave my church, my poorâGodâs poor,
To a dark and prayerless grave?
No! by the body of my Lord,
My skin I will not save!â
And when men heard his true, strong word,
They bore them as men should,
For twenty nights and twenty days
The foemen they withstood,
And, day and night, shone tapers bright,
And incense veiled the rood.
The warriors manned the walls without,
The monks prayed on within,
Till Satan, wroth to see how prayer
And valour fared to win,
Whispered a traitor, who stole out
And let the foemen in.
Then through the quiet church there ran
A sudden breath of fear;
The monks made haste to bar the door,
And hide the golden gear;
And to their lord once more they cried,
âHide, hide! the foe is here!â
Through all the churchâs windows showed
The sudden laugh of flame;
Along the street went trampling feet,
And through the smoke there came
The voice of women, calling shrill
Upon the Saviourâs name.
And âHide! oh, hide!â the monks all cried,
âNor meet such foes as these!â
âBe still,â he said, âhide if ye will,
Live on, and take your ease!
By my Lordâs death, my latest breath,
Like His, shall speak of peace!â
He strode along the dusky aisle,
And flung the church doors wide;
Bright armour shone, and blazing homes
Lit up the world outside,
And in the streets reeled to and fro
A bloody human tide.
The mailed barbarians laughed aloud
To see the brave blood flow;
They trampled on the breast and hair
Of girls their swords laid low,
And on the points of reeking spears
Tossed babies to and fro.
Alphege stood forth; his pale face gleamed
Against the dark red tide.
âForbear, your cup of guilt is full!
Your sins are red,â he cried;
âSpare these poor sheep, my lambs, for whom
The King of Heaven died!â
Drunken with blood and lust of fight,
Loud laughed Thorkill the Dane.
âStand thou and see us shear thy sheep
Before thy foolish fane!
Hear how they weep! They bleat, thy sheep,
That thou mayst know their pain!â
He stood, and saw his monks all slain;
The altar steps ran red;
In horrid heaps men lay about,
The dying with the dead;
And the east brightened, and the sky
Grew rosy overhead.
Then from the church a tiny puff
Of smoke rose âgainst the sky,
Out broke the fire, and flame on flame
Leaped palely out on high,
Till but the churchâs walls were left
For men to know it by.
And when the sweet sun laughed again
Oâer fields and furrows brown,
The brave archbishop hid his eyes,
Until the tears dropped down
On the charred blackness of the wreck
Of Canterbury town.
âNow, Saxon shepherd, send a word
Unto thy timid sheep,
And bid them greaten up their hearts,
And to our feet dare creep,
And bring a ransom here which we,
Instead of thee, may keep.â
Archbishop Alphege stood alone,
Bruised, beaten, wearyâeyed;
Loaded with chains, with aching heart,
And wounded in the side;
And in his hour of utmost pain
Thus to the Dane replied:
âYe men of blood, my blood shall flow
Before this thing shall be;
If I be held till ransom come,
I never shall be free;
For by Godâs heart, Godâs poor shall never
Be robbed to ransom me!â
They flung him in a dungeon dark,
They heaped on him fresh chains,
They promised him unnumbered ills
And unimagined pains;
But still he said, âNo English shall
Be taxed to profit Danes!â
The months passed by; no ransom came;
Their threats had almost ceased,
When Thorkill held, on EasterâEve,
A great and brutal feast;
And they sent and dragged the Christian man
Before the pagan beast.
Down the great hall, from east to west,
The long rough tables ran;
They roasted oxen, sheep, and deer,
And then the drink beganâ
At last in all that mighty hall
Was not one sober man.
âTwas then they brought the bishop forth
Before the drunken throng;
And âSend for ransom!â Thorkill cried,
âYou are weak, and we are strong,
Or, by the hand of Thor, you dieâ
We have borne with you too long!â
The savage faces of the Danes
Leered redly all around;
The bones of beasts and empty cups
Lay heaped upon the ground,
And âmid the crowd of howling wolves
The Christian saint stood bound.
He looked in Thorkillâs angry eyes
And knew what thing should be,
Then spake: âBy God, who died to save
The poor, and me, and thee,
Thou art not strong enoughâGodâs poor
Shall not be taxed for me!â
âGold! Give us gold, or die!â All round
The rising tumult ran.
âI give my life, I give Godâs word,
I give what gifts I can!
Bleed Christian sheep for pagan wolves?
Find you some other man!â
And, as he spake, the whole crowd rose
With one fierce shout and yell;
They flung at him the bones of beasts,
They aimed right strong and well.
âO Christ, O Shepherd, guard Thy sheep!â
The bishop criedâand fell.
And so men call him âSaint,â yet some
Deemed this an unearned crown,
Since âtwas not for the Church or faith
He laid his brave life down;
But otherwise men deemed of it
In Canterbury town.
âNot for the Church he died,â they said,
âYet he our saint shall be,
Since for Christâs poor he gave his life,
So for Christâs self died he.
âWho does it to the least of these,
Has done it unto Me!â
BETWEEN the midnight and the morn
When wake the weary heart and head,
Troops of gray ghosts from lands forlorn
Keep tryst about my sleepless bed.
I hear their cold, thin voices say:
âYour youth is dying; byâandâby
All that makes up your life toâday
Withered by age, will shrink and die!â
Will it be so? Will age slay all
The dreams of love and hope and faithâ
Put out the sun beyond recall,
And lap us in a living death?
Will hearts grown old forget their youth?
And hands grown old give up the strife?
Shall we accept as ordered truth
The dismal anarchy of life?
Better die nowâat once be free
Of hope and fearârenounce the whole:
For of what worth would living be
Should oneâgrown oldâoutlive oneâs soul?
Yet see: through curtains closely drawn
Creeps in the exorcising light;
The sacred fingers of the dawn
Put all my troop of ghosts to flight.
And then I hear the brave Sunâs voice,
Though still the skies are gray and dim;
âOld age comes neverâOh, rejoiceâ
Except to those who beckon him.
âAll that youthâs dreams are nourished by,
By that shall dreams in age be fedâ
Thy noble dreams can never die
Until thyself shall wish them dead!â
FLUSHED with a crimson sunrise beauty,
The fair new year its promise gave;
Such dreams we had of love, of duty,
Of heights to scale, of foes to brave!
Oh, how hopeâs fire our future lightedâ
How much to do, how much to know,
Yet on its brink we shrank affrighted
A year ago.
And now the year is doneâits pleasure
So brief, so brightâits hours of pain;
Some momentsâ memories we treasure,
Some recollections loathe in vain.
Oh, for a brain where could not waken
Remembrances of purpose crossed,
Of trusts abandoned, aims forsaken,
And chances lost!
The changing seasons thrust upon us
Another year, fairâfaced and new;
What evil have the old years done us
That this in its turn will not do?
This, too, will die, and leave us grieving
For all the ills its arms enfoldâ
For faiths betrayed, for friends deceiving,
And love grown cold.
We have been fooled. The hopes that fooled usâ
We know them nowâhave been a lie;
The star that led, the light that ruled usâ
We scorn them, and we pass them by.
Shut out hopeâs light; past is the season
When roseâred glow seemed good to see.
Lookâby the cold white light of reason,
These things shall be:
A long, dim vista, blank and drearyâ
The same hard failure, small success;
The same tired heart, the brain still weary
Of its intense selfâconsciousness;
The old despair, the old repining,
And through the futureâs deepest night,
Down lifeâs untrodden ways still shining,
The old hopeâs light!
THE flood of utter change is loosed. A space
Is ours yet, for its coming to prepare.
Shall we build dams with cautious, clumsy care,
Or stand with idle hands and frightened face,
And so be whirled all broken from our place,
Or perish with the dams we builded there?
Or shall we dig a broad, deep channel, where
Most fields may feel the flood's benign embrace?
Thus turned âtwill be a calm majestic flood
Of plenty, peace, and fertilising power,
Whose banks fresh flowers of love and joy shall deck.
Oppose it: at the inevitable hour,
Tumultuous, black with ruin, red with blood,
âTwill comeâand you shall have no chance but wreck!

epigraph.p: A priest tells how, in his youth, a church was built by the free labour of loveâas was menâs wont in those days; and how the stone and wood were paid for by one who had grown rich on usury and the pillage of the poorâand of what chanced thereafter.

lg.l: ARSENIUS, priest of God, I tell,
For warning in your younger ears,
Humbly and plainly what befell
That yearâhone by a many yearsâ
When Veraignes church was built. Ah! then
Brave churches grew âneath hands of men:
We see not now their like again.
We built it on the green hillâside
That leans its bosom oâer the town,
So that its presence, sanctified,
Might ever on our lives look down.
We built; and those who built not, they
Brought us their blessing day by day,
And lingered to rejoice and pray.
For years the masons toiled, for years
The craftsmen wrought till they had made
A church we scarce could see for tearsâ
Its fairness made our love afraid.
Its richâwrought silver tracery
Stood out against the deep bright sky
Like good deeds âgainst eternity.
In the deep roof each separated beam
Had its own garlandâivy, vine,â
Giving to man the carverâs dream,
In sight of men a certain signâ
And all day long the workers plied.
âThe church shall finished be,â we cried,
âAnd consecrate by Easterâtide.â
Our church! It was so fair, so dear,
So fit a church to praise God in!
It had such show of carven gear,
Such chiselled work, without, within!
Such marble for the steps and floor,
Such windowâjewels and such store
Of gold and gems the altar bore!
Each stone by loving hands was hewn,
By loving hands each beam was sawn;
The hammers made a merry tune
In winter dusk and summer dawn.
Love built the house, but gold had paid
For that wherewith the house was made.
âWould love had given all!â we said.
But poor in all save love were we,
And he was poor in all save gold
Who gave the gold. By usury
Were gained his riches manifold.
We knew that? If we knew, we thought
âTis good if men do good in aught,
And by good works may heaven be bought!
At last the echo died in air
Of the last stroke. The silence then
Passed in to fill the church, left bare
Of the loving voice of Christian men.
The silence saddened all the sun,
So gladly was our work begun.
Now all that happy work was done.
Did any voices in the night
Call through those arches? Were there wings
That swept between the pillars whiteâ
Wide pinions of unvisioned things?
The priests who watched the relics heard
Wingâwhispersânot of bat or birdâ
And moan of inarticulate word.
Then sunlight, morning, and sweet air
Adorned our church, and there were borne
Great sheaves of boughs of blossoms fair
To grace the consecration morn.
Then round our church trooped knight and dame;
Within, alone, the bishop came,
And the twelve candles leaped to flame.
Then round our church the bishop went
With all his priestsâa brave array.
There was no sign nor portent sent
As, glad at heart, he went his way,
Sprinkling the holy water round
Three times on walls and crowd and ground
Within the empty churchyardâs bound.
Thenâbut ye know the functionâs scope
At consecrationâall the show
Of torch and incense, stole and cope;
And how the acolytes do go
Before the bishopâhow they bear
The lighted tapers, flaming fair,
Blown back by the sweet wavering air.
The bishop, knocking at the door,
The deacon answering from within,
âLift up your heads, ye gates, be sure
The King of Glory shall come inââ
The bishop passed in with the choir.
Thank God for thisâour soulâs desire,
Our altar, meet for heavenâs fire!
The bishop, kneeling in his place
Where our bright windows made day dim,
With all heavenâs glory in his face,
Began the consecration hymn:
âVeni,â he sang, in clear strong tone.
Thenâon the instantâsong was done,
Its very echo scatteredâgone!
For, as the bishopâs voice rang clear,
Another voice rang clearer stillâ
A voice wherein the soul could hear
The discord of unmeasured illâ
And sudden breathless silence fell
On all the church. And I wot well
There are such silences in hell.
Taper and torch died downâwent outâ
And all our church grew dark and cold,
And deathly odours crept about,
And chill, as of the churchyard mould;
And every flower drooped its head,
And all the roseâs leaves were shed,
And all the lilies dropped down dead.
There, in the bishopâs chair, we sawâ
How can I tell you? Memories shrink
To mix anew the cup of awe
We shuddering mortals had to drink.
What was it there? The shape that stood
Before the altar and the roodâ
It was not human flesh and blood!
A light more bright than any sun,
A shade more dark than any night,
A shape that human shape was none,
A cloud, a sense of wingÃ«d might,
And, like an infernal trumpet sound,
Rang through the churchâs hush profound
A voice. We listened horrorâbound.
âVenio! Cease, cease to consecrate!
Love built the church, but it is mine!
âTis built of stone hewn out by hate,
Cemented by manâs blood divine.
Whence came the gold that paid for this?
From pillage of the poor, I wisâ
That gold was mine, and mine this is!
âYour King has cursed the usurerâs gold,
He gives it to me for my fee!
Your church is builded, but behold
Your church is fair for meâfor me!
Who robs the poor to me is given;
Impenitent and unforgiven,
His church is built for hell, not heaven!â
Then, as we gazed, the face grew clear,
And all men stood as turned to stone;
Each man beheld through dews of fear
A faceâhis ownâyet not his own;
His own face, darkened, lost, debased,
With hellâs own signet stamped and traced,
And all the God in it effaced.
A crash like thunder shook the walls,
A flame like lightning shot them through:
âFly, fly before the judgment falls,
And all these stones be fallen on you!â
And as we fled we saw bright gleams
Of fire leap out âmid joists and beams.
Our church! Oh, loveâoh, hopesâoh, dreams!
We stood withoutâa pallid throngâ
And as the flame leaped high and higher,
Shrill winds we heard that rushed along
And fanned the transports of the fire.
The sky grew black; against the sky
The blue and scarlet flames leaped high,
And cries as of lost souls wailed by.
The church in glowing vesture stood,
The lead ran down as it were wax,
The great stones cracked and burned like wood,
The wood caught fire and flamed like flax:
A horrid chequered light and shade,
By smoke and flame alternate made,
Upon menâs upturned faces played.
Down crashed the walls. Our lovely spire,
A blackened ruin, fell and lay.
The very earth about caught fire,
And flameâtongues licked along the clay.
The fire did neither stay nor spare
Till the foundations were laid bare
To the hot, sickened, smokeâfilled air.
There in the sight of men it lay,
Our church that we had made so fair!
A heap of ashes white and gray,
With sparks still gleaming here and there.
The sun came out again, and shone
On all our loving work undoneâ
Our church destroyed, our labour gone!
Gone? Is it gone? God knows it, no!
The hands that builded built aright:
The men who loved and laboured so,
Their church is built in heavenâs height!
In every stone a glittering gem,
Gold in the gold Jerusalemâ
The church their love built waits for them.
THE garden mould was damp and chill,
Winter had had his brutal will
Since over all the yearâs content
His devastating legions went.
Then Springâs bright banners came: there woke
Millions of little growing folk
Who thrilled to know the winter done,
Gave thanks, and strove towards the sun.
Not so the elect; reserved, and slow
To trust a strangerâsun and grow,
They hesitated, cowered and hid
Waiting to see what others did.
Yet even they, a little, grew,
Put out prim leaves to day and dew,
And lifted level formal heads
In their appointed garden beds.
The gardener came: he coldly loved
The flowers that lived as he approved,
That duly, decorously grew
As he, the despot, meant them to.
He saw the wildlings flower more brave
And bright than any cultured slave;
Yet, since he had not set them there,
He hated them for being fair.
So he uprooted, one by one
The free things that had loved the sun,
The happy, eager, fruitful seeds
That had not know that they were weeds.
LEAVE me alone, for Augustâs sleepy charm
Is on me, and I will not break the spell;
My head is on the mighty Motherâs arm:
I will not ask if life goes ill or well.
There is no world!âI do not care to know
Whence aught has come, nor wither it shall go.
I want to wander over pastures still,
Where sheared white sheep and mildâeyed cattle graze;
To climb the thymy, cloverâcovered hill,
To look down on the valleyâs hot blue haze;
And on the short brown turf for hours to lie
Gazing straight up into the clear, deep sky.
I want to walk through crisp gold harvest fields,
Through meadows yellowed by the August heat;
To loiter through the cool dim wood, that yields
Such perfect flowers and quiet so completeâ
The happy woods, where every bud and leaf
Is full of dreams as life is full of grief.
I want to think no more of all the pain
That in the city thrives, a poisonâflowerâ
The eternal loss, the neverâcoming gain,
The lifelong woeâthe joy that lives an hour,
Bright, evanescent as the dew that dawn
Shows on this silent, woodâencircled lawn.
I want to pull the honeyâbud that twines
About the blackberries and goldâleaf sloes;
To part the boughs where the rare water shines,
Tread the soft bank whereby the bulrush growsâ
I want to be no more myself, but be
Made one with all the beauty that I see.
Oh, happy country, myriad voiced and dear,
I have no heart, no eyes, except for you;
Yours are the only voices I will hear,
Yours is the only bidding I will do:
You bid me be at peace, and let alone
That loud, rough world where peace is never known.
Yet through your voices comes a sterner cry,
A voice I cannot silence if I would;
It mars the song the lark sings to the sky,
It breaks the changeful music of the wood.
âBack to your postâa charge you have to keepâ
Freedom is bleeding while her soldiers sleep.â
Oh, heart of mine I have to carry here,
Will you not let me rest a little while?â
A space âmid doubtful fight and doubtful fearâ
A little space to see the Motherâs smile,
To stretch my hands out to her, and possess
No sense of aught but of her loveliness?
Ah, just this power to feel how she is fair
Means just the power to see how foul life is.
How can I linger in the sacred air
And taste the pure wine of the dear sunâs kiss
When in the outer dark my brothers moan,
Nor even guess the joys that I have known?
Back the least soldier goes! To jar and fret,
To hope uncrownedâfaith friedâlove wounded soreâ
To prayers that never have been answered yet,
To dreams that may be dreams for evermore;
To all that, after all, is far more dear
Than all the joys of all the changing year.
SPRING!âalmost summer! The winterâs gone,
His reign is over, his hour is done!
Hereâs the crumpled green of the newâborn leaves,
Here are babyâsparrows âneath cottage eaves;
And the apple orchards are thick with bloom,
And the woods are gathering their summer gloom;
And the cottage gardens are gay and bright
With the wallflower brown and the rockâplant white;
And the heart of the risen year beats free
In meadow and forest, in flower and tree;
It beats in the prisoned hearts of men,
Till vaguely, vainly they long again
For the joy that is promised by every spring,
The joy no summer will ever bring.
And the children wander by field and brake,
And clap their hands for the daisiesâ sake.
The bountiful summer laughs and throws
Her garment of green and her wreath of rose
On great vile cities that men have raised,
Where her name is unloved, unknown, unpraised,
And only gold is counted of worth
Of all the gifts of the goodly earth.
And in this desert that men have made
Grow whiteâfaced children that never played
With daisies and cowslips, nor laughed and lay
On the hot gray heaps of the scented hayâ
The poor pale children who never have heard
The perfect song of an uncaged bird:
They never have gathered a growing flower,
Or strayed through a wood for a truant hourâ
They sit in groups and they seem to wait,
Unfriended and hopeless and desolate.
Do they wait for the hero who is to come
To teach them the meaning of love and homeâ
To take them away from the heavy frown
Of the high black walls and the cruel town,
To where there is light and a rest from noise,
And love for the children of men, and toys?
Who is to save them? Ah! I and you
Have the chance and the choice this fair deed to do.
Where Gold is god, there the children must
Be ground âneath his wheels in the bloody dust;
But if Love be godâand a temple raised
Where gold shall be cursÃ¨d and love be praisedâ
When the temple is clean and the altar fair,
The children their garlands shall bring and bear
The first of all who shall gather there!
WHEN we sow the good seed of the present,
That the future will garner and gain,
For whom do we till, weed, and water,
For whom watch the sun and the rain,
With passionate faith that our waiting
And labour will not be in vain?
Not the men and the women about usâ
Themselves but themselves can make free;
Not they, more than we, the full harvest
Of the seed we are sowing will see;
But the fruits will be reaped by the childrenâ
The men and the women to be.
O, the children!âthe roseâleaf soft faces,
The sweet little voices, and mild,
The arms that have clung and caressed us,
The lips that have babbled and smiled,â
Have these blinded us so we discern not
That a child is not only a child?
Not only a toy and a treasure
For motherâs and fatherâs delight,
Not only a flower want may wither,
Or lovelessness ruin and blight,
But a soul to be saved, in Truthâs sunshine,
Or lost where Truthâs absence makes night.
And the souls that shall shape the worldâs future
Are the souls we are shaping toâday!
Let the children have share in our justice,
Not just in our pity and play.
They will do the worldâs work, and our work is
To show them the work and the way.
And he who is helping the children,
Who are frail as the buds of a rose,
Who is keeping the canker from blighting
The blossoms before they unclose,
And making the future sons hardy
To face all the futureâs fell foes,â
He is doing the worldâs work eternal
That the first dawn of soul saw begun;
He is hastening the hour when the children
The battles we lost will have won:
When the deeds that we did not, and could not,
Those small handsâgrown strongâwill have done.
THE lilies in my garden grow,
Wide meadows ring my garden round,
In that green copse wild violets blow,
And pale, frail cuckoo flowers are found.
For all you see and all you hear,
The city might be miles away,
And yet you feel the city near
Through all the quiet of the day.
Sweet smells the earth, wet with sweet rain,
Sweet lilac waves in moonlight pale,
And from the wood beyond the lane
I hear the hidden nightingale.
Though field and wood about me lie,
Hushed soft in dew and deep delight,
Yet can I hear the cityâs sigh
Through all the silence of the night.
For me the skylark nests and sings,
For me the vine her garland weaves;
The swallow folds her glossy wings
To build beneath my cottage eaves.
But I can feel the giant near,
Can hear his slaves by daylight weep,
And, when at last the night is here,
I hear him moaning in his sleep.
Oh! for a little space of ground,
Though not a flower should make it gay,
Where miles of meadows wrapped me round,
And leagues and leagues of silence lay.
Oh! for a windâlashed, treeless down,
A black night and a rising sea,
And never a thought of London town,
To steal the worldâs delight from me!
FOR what wilt thou sell thy Lord?
âFor certain pieces of silver, since wealth buys the worldâs good word.â
But the worldâs word, how canst thou hear it, while thy brothers cry scorn on thy name?
And who shall thy bargain content thee, when thy brothers shall clothe thee with shame?
For what shall thy brother be sold?
âFor the rosy garland of pleasure, and the coveted crown of gold.â
But thy soul will turn them to thorns, and to heaviness binding thy head,
While women are dying of shame, and children are crying for bread.
For what wilt thou sell thy soul?
âFor the world.â And what shall it profit, when thou shalt have gained the whole?
What profit the things thou hast, if the thing thou art be so mean?
Wilt thou fill, with the husks of having, the void of the mightâhaveâbeen?
âBut, when my soul shall be gone,
No more shall I fail to profit by all the deeds I have done!
And wealth and the world and pleasure shall sing sweet songs in my ear
When the stupid soul is silenced, which never would let me hear.
âAnd if a void there should be
I shall not feel it or know it; it will be nothing to me!â
It will be nothing to thee, and thou shalt be nothing to men
But a ghost whose treasure is lost, and who shall not find it again.
âBut I shall have pleasure and praise!â
Praise shall not pleasure thee then, nor pleasure laugh in thy days:
For as colour is not, without light, so happiness is not, without
Thy Brother, the Lord whom thou soldestâand the soul that thou hast cast out!
WHEN head and hands and heart alike are weary;
When Hope with folded wings sinks out of sight;
When all thy striving fails to disentangle
From out wrongâs skein the golden threads of right;
When all thy knowledge seems a marshâlightâs glimmer,
That only shows the blackness of the night;
In the dark hour when victory seems hopeless,
Against thy lance when armies are arrayed,
When failure writes itself upon thy forehead,
By foes outnumbered and by friends betrayed;
Still stand thou fast, though faith be bruised and wounded,
Still face thy future, still be undismayed!
While one true man speaks out against injustice,
While through menâs chorused âRight!â clear rings his âWrong!â
Freedom still lives. One day she will reward him
Who trusted in her though she tarried long,
Who held her creed, was faithful till her coming,
Who, for her sake, strove, suffered, and was strong.
She will bring crowns for those who love and serve her;
If thou canst live for her, be satisfied;
If thou canst die for her, rejoice! Our brothers
At least shall crown our graves and say, âThese died
Believing in the sun when night was blackest,
And by our dawn their faith is justified!â
I SAW a people trampled on, oppressed,
With helpless hands, and eyes of light afraid,
With aching shoulders whereon burdens laid
By day and night choked hope and murdered rest;
A people sordid, sad, unloved, unblessed,
Whose shroud by their own hands was ever made,
Whose neverâending toil was only paid
By deathâinâlifeâor death, of lifeâs gifts best.
âWhat help,â I cried, âfor these whose hands are weakâ
Too weak to hold the weapons they should wield;
Too weak to grasp a helping hand, or seek
With armed battalions to dispute the field,
And on the oppressors just revenge to wreak?â
Thenâas I criedâthe helper was revealed.
I saw a woman, pure, and calm, and grand,
With strong broad brows, and eyes whose keen clear flame
Lit up menâs hearts and showed them glory and shame,
And what things could, and what things could not stand,
Justice and Honour stood at her right hand;
And blazoned on her forehead was her name,
Too bright for me to read; and as she came
Men bowed and worshipped her through all the land.
And evil could not live before her eyes,
And good rose up to answer her call.
âWho art thou,â then I said, âthat dost arise
Strong to redeem this people from their thrall?â
She answered me with tender voice and wise:
âMy name is Knowledgeâand I conquer all!â

div.head: A Star in the East
For the first Art Exhibition at St. Judeâs, Whitechapel

lg.l: LIKE a fair flower springing fresh, sweet, and bright,
Through prison stones; or like one perfect song
Heard in a dream on one remembered night,
When waking worlds were dumb with grief and wrong;
Like the one kiss that linksâfirst kiss and lastâ
The inevitable future spent apart
With the immutable divided past;
So in the east shines out this star of Art.
The narrowâshouldered, paleâfaced girl and boy
Nestle against Artâs newâfound, loveâwarm breast,
And feel vague stirrings of a farâoff joy,
Which life has never for themselves possessed.
And dimly guess at wonders hardly known
Even as dreamsâand weep glad tears to see
A loveliness that is at once lifeâs own,
And yet is something life can never be.
Not worse will work the flying busy hand
Because the soul has drunk a cup of pleasure,
Has picked up on its leadenâcoloured strand
Some little jewel of Artâs splendid treasure,
Nor will less work be done because men see
That work is not the only thing in life,
Because they have been glad at heart and free
A little space âmid sorrow, sin, and strife.
And this sweet draught may banish menâs content?
For this we pray and striveânot all in vainâ
That men may reach such heights of discontent
As never to fall back to peace again
Where no peace isânor rest from strife and prayers,
But tread firmâfooted up the thorny way,
Till all that spring of art and joy is theirs
Whereof they taste so small a draught toâday.
I BOUGHT you flowers on Ludgate Hill,
Dear violets in December,
And all the way to Charing Cross
They whispered of the rainâwet moss,
The budding briars, the April days,
The pageant of the woodland ways,
And all the pleasant plots and plays
That you and I remember.
I met you on the platform chill
Where winter winds were snarling;
Your smile that lit that gloomy place
Lit up for me that other face
Of her who sold the violetsâmean,
Poor, broken, desolate, unclean:
A ruined slave, who might have been
A Queen like you, my darling.
âTHE spring is here!â the primrose says;
The birds exultââThe spring is here!â
A veil of buds, desire and dear,
Is thrown across the lengthening days.
The furrowed field that was so brown
Is faintly gray with wet green spears,
Which shall be fruitful wheaten ears,
The golden autumnâs golden crown.
The sticky chestnutâbuds unfold,
The almondâblossom pinkly gleams;
The freshness of our childhoodâs dreams
Is on the moor, the wood, the wold.
The fat, blithe blackbirds on the lawn
Rejoice to see the grass grown green;
And starlings, where the thatched roofs lean,
Chatter in gray and windy dawn.
And spring is hereâbut with the spring
Come bitter winds, and cold, cold showers:
Will these not slay the wakening flowers
And stay the buds from blossoming?
Noâin despite of wind and rain,
The year will add to flowers new flowers,
Till summer comes with burning hours,
And all the roses live again.
And weâno chill that time can bring,
No icy wind of worldly scorn,
Shall ever make our souls forlorn
Of this sweet promise of the spring!
No cold, nor rain, nor wind is strong
To slay Hopeâs seed our hearts within;
Freedom, we know, at last shall win,
Though Tyranny endures so long!
âTIS weary treading every day
The same dull, dreary, uphill way,
While the desired and the divine
So fair and far above us shineâ
As unattainable as dear
To us who grope and stumble here.
âTis hard to hold our flag on high,
And never faint, until we dieâ
To spread our banner on a wind
Scented with garlands left behind:
To give up all lifeâs joy, that we
May humble bannerâbearers be.
âTis hard to sing, in faith, of light
Through endless seeming hours of nightâ
To tune the harp, the voice upraise
For Freedomâs sake, for Honourâs praiseâ
To sing of good that is, not seemsâ
To sing of duties, not of dreams.
âTis hard to fix oneâs sleepy eyes
On faint, faint streaks of new sunrise,
When all oneâs being yearns to weep
Its tiredness out, and turn to sleep:
Sleep and forget, and cease to care
If sunrise be, if darkness were.
âTis weary fighting all oneâs life
In one long, bitter, desperate strife,
The hydraâheaded, rampant wrong,
When one is fain of dance and songâ
To smell the rose, and hear the fair
Soft wings of Pleasure in the air.
Yet would we choose the weary way,
The fighting, not the feasting dayâ
To wear the armour, not the flowers,
To sing of Truth while voice is ours;
Because good fightâs worst wounds are far
More dear than any pleasures are.
I WILL not hear thy music sweet!
If I should listen, then I know
I should no more know friend from foe,
But follow thy capricious feetâ
Thy sings, than mine so much more fleetâ
I will not go!
I will not go away! Away
From reeds and pool why should I go
To where sun burns, and hot winds blow?
Here sleeps cool twilight all the day;
Do I not love thy tune? No, no!
I will not say!
I will not say I love thy tune;
I do not know if so it be;
It surely is enough for me
To know I love cool rest at noon,
Spread thy bright wingsâah, goâgo soon!
I will not see!
I will not see thy gleaming wings,
I will not hear thy music clear.
It is not love I feel, but fear;
I love the song the marshâfrog sings,
But thine, which afterâsorrow brings,
I will not hear!
O GOD, let there be rain!
Rain, till this sky of gray
That covers us every day
Be utterly wept away,
Let there be rain, we pray,
Till the sky be washed blue again
Let there be rain!
O God, let there be rain,
For the sky hangs heavy with pain,
And we, who walk upon the earth,
We find our days not of worth;
None blesses the day of our birth,
We question of deathâs day in vain,â
Let there be rain.
O God, let there be rain
Till the fullâfed earth complain.
Yes, though it sweep away
The seeds sown yesterday
And beat down the blossoms of May
And ruin the border gay:
In storm let this gray noon wane,
Let there be rain!
O God, let there be rain
Till the rivers rise aâmain!
Though the waters go over us quite
And over us up from the light
And whelm us away in the night
And the flowers of our life be slain,
O God, let there be rain!
O God, let there be rain,
Out of the gray sky, rain!
To wash the earth and to wash the sky
And the sick, sad souls of the folk who sigh
In the gray of a sordid satiety.
Open Thy floodâgates, O God most High,
And some day send us the sun again.
O God, let there be rain!
ITâS all for nothing: Iâve lost im now.
I suppose it ad to be:
But oh I never thought it of im,
Nor e never thought it of me.
And all for a kiss on your evening out
An a field where the grass was down . . .
And e as gone to Godâknowsâwhere,
